channel.description: World News Today: Read the latest world news headlines, Current International breaking news world wide. In depth analysis and top news headlines world wide.

image.title: World News Today, Trending World News, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: 'Very sorry for causing anxiety': South Korea's President Yoon apologises for declaring martial law
item.description: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol apologized for declaring martial law, acknowledging public anxiety. Facing an impeachment vote, he expressed remorse but stopped short of resigning, leaving his future to his party. Yoon assured the nation there would be no further martial law declarations and accepted accountability for his actions.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Late-night K-drama leaves democracy in suspense
Trump's Middle East envoy engages in high-stakes talks to end Gaza conflict and release Israeli hostages
item.description: Trump's Middle East envoy, Steven Witkoff, engaged in pre-inauguration talks with Qatari and Israeli officials, aiming to secure a Gaza ceasefire and the release of Israeli hostages held by Hamas. Trump demanded their release by January 20. Hamas seeks a permanent ceasefire and Israeli withdrawal, facing resistance from Netanyahu's coalition. Mediation efforts are ongoing amidst the 14-month conflict.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: TikTok advertisers stay put after US appeals court upholds law forcing sale
item.description: A U.S. appeals court upheld a law potentially banning TikTok, but advertisers remain unfazed, maintaining campaigns while preparing backup plans. Rivals like Meta and YouTube stand to gain if TikTok is banned, boosting their stock prices. TikTok's fate now rests with a potential Supreme Court appeal.

item.title: How UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson’s killer escaped: From cycle to taxi to bus
item.description: Police are investigating the fatal shooting of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson outside a NYC hotel. The suspect, believed to be a disgruntled employee or client, fled by bus after cycling through Central Park. He arrived from Atlanta on November 24th and used a fake ID at a hostel. The ammunition had the words "deny," "defend," and "depose" written on it.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Stowaway who boarded New York-to-Paris flight claims she sought asylum in France
item.description: A Russian woman with US residency, Svetlana Dali, was arrested after stowing away on a Delta flight from New York to Paris. Dali bypassed security by slipping through an employee lane. Upon arrival in Paris, she was detained and returned to the US. Dali claims she was poisoned in Paris and subjected to inhumane treatment at a Brooklyn detention center.

item.title: Obtaining bail is a right, monk Chinmoy Krishna Das' plea must be heard, religious heads tell Yunus
item.description: Minority religious leaders in Bangladesh have appealed to interim government chief adviser Muhammad Yunus to consider the bail plea of Hindu monk Chinmoy Krishna Das, facing sedition charges. A bail hearing is rescheduled for January 2nd. Two individuals were remanded in Chittagong concerning the death of Saiful Islam Alif, who died in clashes following the denial of Das's bail.

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle deeply ‘hurt’ by German documentary, claims source
item.description: A new German documentary, "Harry - The Lost Prince," has sparked controversy, exploring Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's lives as charity ambassadors. The documentary features critical commentary from neighbors, security officials, and former colleagues, leading to feelings of hurt and betrayal from the Sussexes.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Two leading British Indian community figures Rami Ranger and Anil Bhanot stripped of their honours by the King
item.description: Two prominent British Indian figures, Rami Ranger and Anil Bhanot, have been stripped of their CBE and OBE honors respectively. Both denounce the move as an attack on free speech, citing complaints related to their public statements.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Canton

item.title: Daniel Penny trial: Judge drops top manslaughter charge, allows lesser charge
item.description: A jury in Manhattan is deadlocked on the manslaughter charge against Daniel Penny, a Marine veteran accused of fatally choking Jordan Neely on a subway train. The judge gave an Allen charge, urging further deliberation. The jury may consider a lesser charge if the deadlock persists. The case has fueled debate about race, mental health, and public safety.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: ‘I did the best I could’: Tim Walz reflects on presidential loss
item.description: In his first post-election interview, Minnesota Governor Tim Walz expressed surprise at the Democratic ticket's loss, reflecting on the perceived momentum that ultimately didn't translate into victory. He acknowledged the need for self-reflection while avoiding direct criticism of Kamala Harris's campaign. Walz has now shifted focus back to Minnesota's evenly split House, expressing optimism about navigating the challenging political landscape.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Could Hawk Tuah girl be arrested for her crypto scam? Truth behind the viral claim
item.description: Hailey Welch, the "Hawk Tuah" girl, launched a cryptocurrency that crashed after reaching a $490 million market cap, leading to accusations of a "pump and dump" scheme and demands for her arrest. Welch denied wrongdoing, claiming her team hadn't sold any tokens, but faces potential legal action from investors who lost millions.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Boston City councilor Tania Fernandes Anderson arrested on federal fraud charges
item.description: Boston City Councilor Tania Fernandes Anderson was arrested on federal fraud charges, accused of orchestrating a kickback scheme involving a relative and misusing public funds. Anderson allegedly gave an inflated bonus to a family member, who then returned a portion of the money to her. Mayor Wu has called for Anderson's resignation, citing a breach of public trust.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Trump taunts Canada at Fox event as crowd chants '51st state' amid tariff threats
item.description: At a Fox Nation awards ceremony, former President Trump recounted threatening Canada with tariffs and claimed his tough stance on immigration led Mexico to curb illegal crossings. He also outlined plans for stricter immigration and election laws, while celebrating his past achievements. Canadian and Mexican officials offered contrasting accounts of their interactions with Trump.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Prince Harry was forced to dismiss Meghan Markle divorce rumors because...
item.description: Prince Harry's statement on rumors of his divorce from Meghan Markle looked forced, according to experts, as if to keep the buzz on as Harry was asked about the constant glare on their lives, not directly about the rumors of divorce. Experts said Harry pounced on the opportunity and mentioned the divorce as both Harry and Meghan were aware of the rumors and saw it as an opportunity to further their brand.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: TikTok faces looming ban in US as appeals court upholds divestment law
item.description: A US appeals court upheld a law mandating ByteDance to divest TikTok's US operations by January 19, 2025, or face a nationwide ban. The ruling intensifies US-China tensions, with TikTok planning a Supreme Court appeal. The decision's enforcement rests with the incoming Biden administration, impacting the social media landscape and US-China relations.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Mannheim knife attack: Stabbed German activist now faces legal action
item.description: Anti-Islam activist Michael Stürzenberger, recently attacked by an Afghan refugee in Mannheim where a policeman died, has been fined €3,600 for inciting hatred. A Hamburg court convicted him for remarks made at a 2020 rally, reducing a prior prison sentence due to the assassination attempt.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Taylor Lorenz defends 'celebrating' Brian Thompson's murder: 'If you have watched...'
item.description: Former Washington Post reporter Taylor Lorenz defended her comments on the murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, stating she was voicing the anger of many Americans facing healthcare system hardships. Lorenz said it was natural for anyone to feel happy because CEOs like Brian Thompson caused the deaths of many people by denying them their insurance coverage -- which is also violence.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Barack Obama accuses GOP of justice system misuse, public reacts: 'Bro lacks a mirror'
item.description: Former US President Barack Obama's remarks at the Democracy Forum sparked controversy. He criticized using the justice system against political rivals, drawing accusations of hypocrisy from Republicans citing Democrats' actions against Trump. Obama described the political landscape as a "doom loop" of polarization, with each side believing the other manipulates the system.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Brian Thompson's killer is not a hitman? 3 reasons why experts think so
item.description: ​Experts who analyzed the CCTV footage claimed that though the killer was deft in handling the gun, he might not be a trained shooter because he had to fire many shots and shooting in the calf is not a sign of a professional hire, they think. Though the killer is yet to be traced, experts feel he was not a professional hitman and probably acted out of personal vendetta.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
